text: as we're getting set up thanks very much
McKenzie for the kind introduction and
it's a real pleasure to be here at AWS
startup day as McKenzie mentioned I'm
CTO at shape security which is a
start-up in Mountain View we protect the
world's largest banks Airlines retailers
insurance companies what with a primary
line of defense for many of the
applications that each of us use on a
daily basis and prior to shape I led
product management for click fraud
protection at Google and click fraud was
the primary threat to our business model
there which was at the time more than
99% pay-per-click advertising so we've
seen a great deal of change in the
security ecosystem in the cyber criminal
ecosystem over the course of the last
couple of decades and I wanted to share
some of those learnings with you guys as
you think about how to approach security
and defending your applications and your
services that you're making available to
the external world because I think that
there are common paths that companies
often go through in terms of investing
in topics like security and there are
probably some changes that we can
observe in how companies are thinking
about those as a result of some
incidents that have occurred over the
last several years so it's gonna give
away what the next slide is as we scroll
a little bit so you'll have to excuse
that but to begin with how many of you
value keeping your personal data private
raise of hands all right and how many of
you would value being able to use
applications that are secure in terms of
their application security alright so
this is a pattern that you see quite
commonly when you ask folks how much
they value topics like privacy and
security so there was a survey that was
conducted a while ago and one of the
things that we saw is that in some cases
people value privacy more than security
in other cases they value security more
than privacy but in Gen
when you ask people whether or not they
value these sorts of concepts the answer
is yes unfortunately when you observe
their behavior one of the things that
you see is that it doesn't necessarily
line up with what they say in the
surveys themselves so this was a study
that was conducted at MIT where they
asked students to give away some of
their friends private information in
exchange for some pizza and it turns out
that that's not only a powerful enough
incentive to violate your friends
privacy but it's also powerful enough
incentive to give away some of your own
security as they discovered in the same
experiment and this is something that
affects the way that people think about
building security and fraud controls
into their applications as well from a
technology industry perspective and no
company is really immune to this except
maybe particularly paranoid companies or
companies that have had bad experiences
before and I think that one of the best
examples of this is the introduction of
security as the number one priority
company-wide at Microsoft in 2003 and so
this was the trustworthy computing
initiative that Bill Gates emailed the
entire company about and it came after
Microsoft had had some very severe
public incidents with the code red worm
taking over hundreds of thousands of
hosts around the world and this
demonstrates a pattern that many
companies fall into but in particular
startups fall into because you have a
limitation on the amount of resources
that are available to be able to invest
in any given endeavor so how many of you
when you embarked on your startup or
whatever project it is that you're
working on right now that the immediate
first step for you was I need to hire a
chief information security officer one
person which is pretty great maybe
you're in the security industry yes so I
think that that's very typical in terms
of the way that startups have to
prioritize their resource allocation and
that process typically looks like this
you want to develop your technology you
want to be able to create that
capability that differentiates you from
everyone else and then you want to be
able to grow that capability you want to
be able to reach traction in the
audience or in the market and when you
do reach a certain amount of traction
when people are using your services at a
certain scale that's when you also
create enough value that you tracked the
attention of folks that want to attack
you
there's a reason then to be able to go
and attack that service extract the
value that's being hidden or being
secured within that service and that's
often when companies experience some
sort of security incident as a result of
that incident companies generally take
action and that action can take various
forms
it usually takes the form of new
defenses being introduced new security
technologies being purchased new
security mechanisms being created
processes being altered a new position
being created in some cases a chief
information security officer for the
first time in many organizations for
more mature organizations the process
often looks like asking themselves what
did we do wrong based on our old
processes and changing those including
sometimes firing their current CISO and
bringing in a new Sissel and so if you
look throughout the industry you see
that there's kind of a musical chairs
game of chief information security
officers that often gets played as a
result of the desire to say that we're
going to make change and demonstrate
that simply by changing some of the
folks that are in responsible for these
positions but there's another layer to
this which is is it even responsible in
the first place to approach security
this way this was an article that came
out in The Chronicle a while ago and it
was discussing the idea of producing
functionality that's going to be used by
a large number of people that has
vulnerabilities introduced inadvertently
nobody intentionally builds in
vulnerabilities but if you don't put
enough attention into protecting your
application against potential
vulnerabilities are you actually being
ear
sponsible if people can be harmed as a
result of that interesting question so I
want to talk a little bit about the term
cyber security and it's been kind of
amusing to me that cyber even without
the security has become synonymous with
cyber security in certain circles
because ten years ago if you were an
information security professional you
didn't call it cyber security in fact
when I started discussing cyber security
with some of my InfoSec colleagues from
Google and with other firms they sort of
looked at me like I had two heads
because that's not what you call it if
you're really someone that is steeped in
this area but what I discovered was that
this is actually the term of art that
has arisen in non technical circles so
when it comes to folks that are
approaching it from a government
perspective or approaching it from a
political science perspective or or from
a business perspective it's actually
called cybersecurity so when I was in
college and studied computer science or
later when I studied management in
neither of those two contexts were there
any cybersecurity courses that were
mandatory or usually even available and
now you see cybersecurity courses
offered in leading business schools you
see security being part of the standard
curriculum of computer science programs
and I think that that's a very positive
thing but that's not the way that it was
10 20 years ago and so the reason that
I've put cyber in quotation marks here
is because this is also a way of
thinking about how terms become
popularized throughout Society first of
all that they start off being called
so-called something so they were it was
originally called so-called
cybersecurity who as journalists
introduced this term to the audience and
then they started to put it in quotation
marks cybersecurity
and by the way if you ever want to make
something trivialized and seem
unimportant just put it in quotation
marks so you know putting someone's
title as co-founder in quotation marks
you can see the reaction that that will
produce and that's exactly what happened
when cybersecurity was treated with this
kind of diminutive
but that's no longer the case
at pretty much every major publication
in the world there is a cybersecurity
reporter or multiple cybersecurity
reporters who have that particular beat
and it's because of the fact that
cybersecurity is not just about esoteric
applications anymore it's about our
daily lives but application security is
a subset of cybersecurity that is not
necessarily well understood so when
you're dealing with your Amazon login
when you're dealing with your airline
login or when you're dealing with
getting information off of any website
those are applications that you need to
defend in a very different way than you
defend your computer so when people
think about protecting those
applications against vulnerabilities
there are a set of activities that some
people have become quite familiar with
in terms of looking for defects in the
way that the software was created that
allow you to create some sort of
catastrophic harm through that
application but there's a difference
between looking for those types of
defects and defending an application
that has already been constructed very
carefully from a security perspective
and has been scrubbed of all of the
standard defects that people would think
of and that's what I would call
application defense and I want to give
you an example of what it looks like if
you have invested millions of dollars in
an application and protecting it from a
security perspective but you still have
a concern around defending that
application against attacks so here is a
real-life attack on a fortune 100
retailer first of all this is what
normal traffic looks like you see the
nice diurnal periodicity of daily
traffic if you're serving customers in a
specific geographic region basically
what it's showing you is that customers
tend to use your site less when they're
asleep than when they're awake and so
this is the pattern that you would
expect to see if you had only organic
traffic this is not the pattern that
this for
100 retailer was seeing they were seeing
something that looked like this instead
and so what we did was we went into
their environment and were able to show
them for the first time the difference
between the organic traffic that was
coming from their real users and the
attack traffic and it was pretty
eye-opening for them to be able to see
that in fact 92 percent of all of the
login traffic that was coming into their
application was coming from attacks now
this is one of the world's largest most
sophisticated companies that had
experienced security incidents in the
past and was investing heavily in
security controls already they didn't
have any obvious defects in their
application and they were not the type
of organization that someone would say
is not taking security seriously and yet
how is it that the vast majority of the
login activity that was occurring on
their application was coming from
attacks that were just sailing past
those security controls well it's
because this is a different type of
vulnerability than the vulnerabilities
that we generally discuss so what is
going on some of you might be familiar
with the OWASP top 10 so the open web
application security project is a
nonprofit that provides education and
guidance on how to protect your
applications against security defects so
the OWASP top 10 is something that you
should all look at if you haven't looked
at it already in terms of thinking about
how to be able to secure your
applications from a traditional security
perspective but if you do all of these
things and you invest very heavily in
creating a secure application that
doesn't necessarily mean that your
application is safe Oh wasp themselves
introduced a new handbook just last year
that discussed all of the different
types of threats that are particularly
enabled through automation that are
still present even when the OWASP top 10
is dealt with and that in fact is what
we're looking at in that fortune 100
retailer example let me tell you about
exactly what was occurring there and
it has to do with passwords specifically
so Jeff Bezos provided some great
guidance a number of years ago for the
industry and you know was one of many
voices saying that we need to approach
security more seriously and at a very
fundamental level we need to learn how
to create better passwords now that
message was pretty successful in terms
of there being widespread recognition of
what's a good password and what's a bad
password it didn't necessarily sink in
to every single circle as far as
educating folks on how to be able to
create truly secure passwords but in
this example of Mark Zuckerberg using a
really simplistic password let's say
that he hadn't used this as his password
let's say that he'd used something that
was much stronger say something like
this something that is definitely hard
to guess but also hard to remember and
hard to type but certainly strong from
an objective standpoint would that have
protected him against having his Twitter
account taken over and the answer is not
necessarily
because the way that Mark Zuckerberg
account was taken over was not from an
attacker simply guessing his password
but knowing that he had used that as a
valid password on another service and in
this case it was on LinkedIn as a result
of a data breach on LinkedIn the
attackers were able to immediately
identify his email address being used
and hypothesized maybe he's using the
same password on Twitter and sure enough
he was linkedin's data breach that was
reported in 2016
made it only the sixth largest data
breach that was reported that year we
actually published a report earlier this
year that tallied up the total number of
passwords which were reported stolen and
it was more than 3.3 billion and those
are just the ones we know about of
course and the ones that were reported
so how are these stolen passwords used
well the best example of this was
actually provided a number of years ago
by Sony now Sony's unfortunately one of
those organizations that has been
attacked so many times we have to talk
about which particular security incident
we're discussing here and this was the
one in 2011 where Sony actually did a
great service for the industry in
sharing what had happened in their
environment so what they explained was
that attackers had obtained 15 million
credentials from completely unrelated
sites and they used them to be able to
login to the Sony Playstation login and
because they'd used a botnet it just
looked like a popular day on their
website you didn't see a million login
requests that were coming in trying to
brute force a single account there was
just one login request per account and
it was distributed across many different
IPs and this is exactly the same pattern
of behavior that you would see if you
had a promotion that went out to a large
portion of your user base so Sony wasn't
prepared for something like this and so
that allowed the attackers to be able to
discover that there were 92 thousand
cases of credential reuse and accounts
that they were able to take over and the
ecosystem has only gotten more
sophisticated since then this is the UI
of Century MBA which is the most popular
credential stuffing tool in the world
this is a simulation tool that allows
attackers to be able to make their
million login requests look like they're
coming from a million different users
you plug in the IP addresses that you've
obtained from one source the credentials
that have been stolen by other cyber
criminals and then century MBA or
orchestrates this attack so that it
looks like it's a bunch of valid login
requests and it knows how to be able to
change all of the behavioral
characteristics associated with those
logins to look like real humans as well
so what ends up happening is you've got
a login form that you've created with
good intention and hopefully with good
security process and practices and
you've designed it so that the only way
that you can authenticate to that
application and get at all of the data
behind it and the functionality behind
it is if you have a valid password so
you think that you've created a very
secure model but now sentry MBA actually
has valid passwords that cybercriminals
are able to use through it to be able to
use that login mechanism against you and
against your users so what about CAPTCHA
so you know CAPTCHA is the most widely
deployed Turing test in the world and a
Turing test of course is the way that
you would guard against simulated user
activity you want to be able to tell the
difference between real human beings and
a computer trying to pretend like it's a
human being
the problem with CAPTCHA is that it just
fundamentally doesn't work so Google
released some stats a couple of years
ago saying that they did a study on
whether or not state of the art machine
learning based optical character
recognition was effective in being able
to solve CAPTCHA and you know the idea
behind CAPTCHA is that it should present
a challenge that is easy for humans to
solve and difficult for machines to be
able to solve and what Google discovered
was that ml based OCR now had a 99.8%
solve rate and real human beings had a
33% solve rate but most of the time we
can't figure out what a CAPTCHA says but
if you present that as a challenge to a
bot or to an attacker they have built-in
tools this is actually the OCR that's
built into sentry MBA to be able to
solve CAPTCHAs and if that built-in OCR
isn't sophisticated enough to be able to
solve the CAPTCHA that's presented there
are also services like death by capcom
which will solve a thousand CAPTCHAs for
you for a dollar thirty nine so all of
this ties together to create what you
might think of as the bad guy version of
AWS so the same way that we appreciate
being
able to use various services being able
to use different components that are
built for us and I love that quote from
Jeff Bezos that Mackenzie mentioned
about being able to get out of the
business of undifferentiated heavy
lifting well cybercriminals have had
those same challenges as well decades
ago when a cybercriminal would create a
botnet they would generally do that for
their own use which was at the time most
commonly sending email spam but today if
you've put together a botnet of millions
of machines you can resell that capacity
to completely unrelated cyber criminals
just to be able to bypass IP based
defenses for whatever purpose those
other cyber criminals want so you've got
this commoditized highly specialized
federated ecosystem that presents a much
more complex challenge than any
individual cyber criminal could ever
present on their own so the question is
how do you protect your services in
light of this level of sophistication
and complexity so because of the work
that I did at Google I was brought in as
an advisor for Facebook Twitter
Pinterest and a number of other firms as
they were setting up their attack
mitigation infrastructures for the first
time and this is the general framework
that I created to be able to discuss all
of the different areas that companies
need to think about investing in in
order to create a comprehensive defense
and there are subcategories to these as
well one of the most powerful is
thinking about your business model
itself what value do you offer that
someone might try and obtain what
incentive do you provide for cyber
criminals to attack you in the first
place if you can make changes to your
business model that's actually the most
leveraged thing that you can do in terms
of having impact to be able to protect
yourself and protect your users but
that's not always or even usually a
practical solution for most
organizations there's probably something
magical about your business model that
enables you to have an opportunity in
the market in the first place so then in
terms of technical defenses there are
various
korie's that you can think of like
reducing your attack surface if there
are ten different ways to be able to
access the data in your application
maybe it would be better if there were
only two or three ways and you protected
those two or three ways extremely well
and redirected everyone to those two or
three ways an example of that is a login
form many organizations just have a
great deal of proliferation of login
forms over time and at some point they
realize you know what we should have a
group that's in charge of Identity and
Access Management for the application
create one login form and protect that
really carefully but all of these areas
are established fields and require a
great deal of thought and investment and
at Google we spent hundreds of millions
of dollars as many large organizations
do to be able to invest in these areas
and create a comprehensive defense that
is not really practical for smaller
organizations especially for startups
and one of the things that heartens me
is the fact that organizations and
services like AWS are changing that
model and so that this might seem a
little strange coming from someone in
the security industry now but I'm going
to advocate that you don't buy security
products instead what I would suggest is
you look for security services so in the
past people would buy something like a
web application firewall and they would
train internal resources to be able to
operate that and then they would have to
keep up to date and then they'd have to
go to the Web Application Firewall user
conference and make sure that they were
completely up to speed on all of the
updates that were coming in that is a
lot of time and effort and it could be
obsolete in a very short period of time
for any given security or fraud
technology it's a lot easier to be able
to just get the benefit of that security
role or fraud control as a service and
the fact that AWS is why for example is
something that you can consume on a per
transaction basis and not worry about
all of the complexity associated with
maintaining it that's something that's
very attractive and there are other
examples in
other areas as well so what I want to
leave you with is that there is a happy
ending to that story that I was relating
to you before about the Fortune 100
retailers so we revealed the organic
traffic to them as well as the 92% of
traffic that was attack traffic but then
we went into what we call blocking mode
and we prevented those transactions from
reaching the origin server and when you
take the fight to the attacker and you
invest in all of those different areas
to be able to create an improvement in
your security posture and in your
overall ability to defend your
application
the attackers respond as well and in
this case what they did was after trying
to retool unsuccessfully they just went
away and attacked someone else the adage
in the security industry is that you
know it's the story of being chased by
the bear that you don't have to be
faster than the bear you just have to be
faster than your friend who's also being
chased and so I think that when it comes
to protecting your application
don't be the easiest target because
that's what cyber criminals are looking
for they're also running businesses
they're organized they have an ROI that
they're hoping to obtain and if you're
the easiest target then they're going to
concentrate their resources on you so
with that thank you very much for your
time and feel free to email me if you
have any questions
[Applause]
